Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: A family holiday is approaching, which is a traditional time for everyone to reconnect.
Expectation2: Secure packages and confirm successful delivery
Situation2: Leaving a package safely at the doorstep when no one is home
Story: I glanced at my phone, a reminder flashing: “Family call at 7 PM—holiday plans.” My daughter had stressed how important it was for everyone to reconnect this year, especially after how distant we’d all become. As a grandfather, I knew how much my presence meant, even if it was just my voice on a screen. But as I pulled up to the next house on my delivery route, I saw the note: “Please don’t leave packages unattended—porch thefts in the area.” The house was dark, no one home, and my shift was running late. My supervisor’s words echoed in my mind: “No exceptions—secure every delivery.” I felt the weight of the package in my hands, the weight of my family’s expectations in my heart. Should I risk a quick call to my family, or focus on making sure this delivery was safe? The clock ticked closer to seven, and I stood on the porch, torn between the warmth of family and the duty of my job, feeling the pressure of both roles pulling me in opposite directions.
